questions.question_text: Which method is a safe way to provide a username/password combination to an application running as a service in a Docker container?

choices.B: as an environment variable in the Dockerfile
choices.A: encode the value with base64 in a secure DNS CTEXT entry

discussion.content:
D is correct. 
a docker secret is a blob of data, such as a password, SSH private key, SSL certificate, or another piece of data that should not be transmitted over a network or stored unencrypted in a Dockerfile or in your application's source code

choices.A: helps by enforcing your password in a repository and storing it in a secure vault
choices.C: helps penetration testing team to focus on other issues more efficiently
choices.D: helps by removing back doors in your environments

questions.question_text: How does eliminating hardcoded or default passwords help to secure an environment?

discussion.content:
D.

Rest do not make sense.

questions.question_text: What is as responsibility for teams running private cloud servers that is less of a concern when running in the public cloud?

discussion.content: C. In private on-prem Cloud you are in charge of maintaining hardware.

questions.question_text: Which two elements help to secure your API keys? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
I believe this would be C & D
A. randomness: maybe, not that is "secures" your key
B. SHA1: easily cracked
C. triple AES: considered secure.
D. rotation: required by ISO 27001
E. dictionary: this is a type of attack, not a secure method
https://www.techtarget.com/searchsecurity/tip/API-keys-Weaknesses-and-security-best-practices
Hash (SHA-1) and rotate API keys (if exposure to Public is high).

choices.A: Verify what the responding file created.
choices.D: Place the code in a container and run the job again.
